item.title: Nevada Voters, Divided Over Health Care, Put Moderate Republican In Tough Spot
item.description: July 7, 2017 - Amid protests during recess, Sen. Dean Heller stayed on the sidelines in his state's health care tug-of-war. Heller is one of the few moderate Republicans expected to have swaying power in the vote.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 7, 2017 - Amid protests during recess, Sen. Dean Heller stayed on the sidelines in his state's health care tug-of-war. Heller is one of the few moderate Republicans expected to have swaying power in the vote. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/07/535962077/nevada-voters-divided-over-health-care-put-moderate-republican-in-tough-spot

item.title: Montana Insurers Say Medicaid Cuts Would Drive Up Cost Of Private Health Plans
item.description: July 7, 2017 - Montana's three main health insurance firms say the Republican Senate's proposed cuts to Medicaid, and any plan to repeal the individual mandate, could drive up health costs for everyone.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 7, 2017 - Montana's three main health insurance firms say the Republican Senate's proposed cuts to Medicaid, and any plan to repeal the individual mandate, could drive up health costs for everyone. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/07/535831120/montana-insurers-say-medicaid-cuts-would-drive-up-cost-of-private-health-plans

item.title: Medicaid Expansion Has Delivered Access To Addiction Treatment, Report Finds
item.description: July 7, 2017 - The Urban Institute reports that Medicaid spending on drugs used to treat opioid addiction and overdoses has risen sharply, raising questions about the potential impact of Medicaid cuts.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 7, 2017 - The Urban Institute reports that Medicaid spending on drugs used to treat opioid addiction and overdoses has risen sharply, raising questions about the potential impact of Medicaid cuts. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/07/535840902/medicaid-expansion-has-delivered-access-to-addiction-treatment-report-finds

item.title: Georgia OB-GYN Will Lead Centers For Disease Control And Prevention
item.description: July 7, 2017 - Dr. Brenda Fitzgerald, who leads the Georgia Department of Public Health, has been appointed CDC director. She'll take over as the Trump administration seeks big cuts to the CDC's budget.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 7, 2017 - Dr. Brenda Fitzgerald, who leads the Georgia Department of Public Health, has been appointed CDC director. She'll take over as the Trump administration seeks big cuts to the CDC's budget. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/07/535954163/georgia-ob-gyn-will-lead-centers-for-disease-control-and-prevention

item.title: Who Would Enjoy Tax Breaks Under The GOP Health Care Proposals?
item.description: July 7, 2017 - The GOP health bills would eliminate many of the taxes that help pay for coverage under the Affordable Care Act. Wealthy individuals stand to gain the most. And customers of tanning salons.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 7, 2017 - The GOP health bills would eliminate many of the taxes that help pay for coverage under the Affordable Care Act. Wealthy individuals stand to gain the most. And customers of tanning salons. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/07/535665925/who-would-enjoy-tax-breaks-under-the-gop-health-care-proposals

item.title: Wisconsin Primary Care Doctor Describes Challenges Of Prescribing Opioids
item.description: July 6, 2017 - A new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says opioid prescriptions are down, but still way too high. While doctors are prescribing lower doses, they are still doing so for longer than CDC guidelines say are safe. NPR's Robert Siegel talks to Dr. Alan Schwartzstein, who has worked as a family doctor for 28 years in rural Wisconsin, about the issues surrounding prescribing pain medication.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 6, 2017 - A new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says opioid prescriptions are down, but still way too high. NPR's Robert Siegel talks to Dr. Alan Schwartzstein, who has worked as a family doctor for 28 years in rural Wisconsin, about the issues surrounding prescribing pain medication. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/06/535823080/wisconsin-primary-care-doctor-describes-challenges-of-prescribing-opioids

item.title: Tell Us: What's Taboo In Global Health And Development?
item.description:
July 6, 2017 - For an upcoming series of stories, we'd like to explore the world of taboos. And we welcome your suggestions.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/07/06/535622255/tell-us-whats-taboo-in-global-health-and-development

item.title: Kansas Sen. Jerry Moran Faces Pressure Over Health Care At Town Hall Event
item.description: July 6, 2017 - Kansas Sen. Jerry Moran is one of the few Republicans holding town hall events this week while Congress is in recess. He is facing pressure over the Senate health care bill.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 6, 2017 - Kansas Sen. Jerry Moran is one of the few Republicans holding town hall events this week while Congress is in recess. He is facing pressure over the Senate health care bill. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/06/535823163/kansas-sen-jerry-moran-faces-pressure-over-health-care-at-town-hall-event

item.title: States Move To Tighten Medicaid Enrollment, Even Without A New Health Law
item.description: July 6, 2017 - Some states are seeking to make major changes in their Medicaid programs that would end coverage for millions of people, even if the Affordable Care Act isn't repealed.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 6, 2017 - Some states are seeking to make major changes in their Medicaid programs that would end coverage for millions of people, even if the Affordable Care Act isn't repealed. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/06/535750231/states-move-to-tighten-medicaid-enrollment-even-without-a-new-health-law

item.title: Opioid Prescriptions Falling But Remain Too High, CDC Says
item.description: July 6, 2017 - U.S. doctors are prescribing opioid painkillers less often and at lower doses, but at rates that are three times higher than their European counterparts, the CDC says.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 6, 2017 - U.S. doctors are prescribing opioid painkillers less often and at lower doses, but at rates that are three times higher than their European counterparts, the CDC says. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/06/535656477/opioid-prescriptions-falling-but-remain-too-high-cdc-says

item.title: To Prepare For Mars Settlement, Simulated Missions Explore Utah's Desert
item.description: July 6, 2017 - NASA plans to send people to the Red Planet in the 2030s. In the meantime, a remote location in southern Utah serves as a non-NASA training ground for the Mars-minded.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 6, 2017 - NASA plans to send people to the Red Planet in the 2030s. In the meantime, a remote location in southern Utah serves as a non-NASA training ground for the Mars-minded. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/06/522060920/to-prepare-for-mars-settlement-simulated-missions-explore-utahs-desert

item.title: 'Architecture Of An Asylum' Tracks History Of U.S. Treatment Of Mental Illness
item.description: July 6, 2017 - Founded in 1855, St. Elizabeths Hospital in Washington, D.C., grew from 250 patients to 8,000. A new exhibit at the National Building Museum explores the links between architecture and mental health.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 6, 2017 - Founded in 1855, St. Elizabeths Hospital in Washington, D.C., grew from 250 patients to 8,000. A new exhibit at the National Building Museum explores the links between architecture and mental health. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/06/535608442/architecture-of-an-asylum-tracks-history-of-u-s-treatment-of-mental-illness

item.title: U.S. Hospitals Struggle To Protect Mothers When Childbirth Turns Deadly
item.description: July 5, 2017 - A joint NPR and ProPublica investigation finds the U.S. medical system can be unprepared when the complications of childbirth turn deadly.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 5, 2017 - A joint NPR and ProPublica investigation finds the U.S. medical system can be unprepared when the complications of childbirth turn deadly. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/05/535660628/u-s-hospitals-struggle-to-protect-mothers-when-childbirth-turns-deadly

item.title: They Dreamed Of Being Doctors. Now They Help Syrians With The Same Dream
item.description: July 5, 2017 - Two Iranian brothers didn't let a war keep them from medical school. Now they're using mobile phones to build the next generation of doctors in Syria.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 5, 2017 - Two Iranian brothers didn't let a war keep them from medical school. Now they're using mobile phones to build the next generation of doctors in Syria. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/07/05/532140694/medical-school-via-mobile-phone-for-some-syrians-it-s-a-growing-option

item.title: Trump's Surgeon General Pick Built Reputation Fighting HIV And Opioids In Indiana
item.description: July 5, 2017 - Dr. Jerome Adams is credited with persuading then-Gov. Mike Pence to authorize syringe exchanges in the state. If confirmed, public health advocates are hopeful he'll have sway in Washington.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 5, 2017 - Dr. Jerome Adams is credited with persuading then-Gov. Mike Pence to authorize syringe exchanges in the state. If confirmed, public health advocates are hopeful he'll have sway in Washington. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/05/535618770/surgeon-general-nominee-championed-policies-to-curb-indiana-s-opioid-epidemic
